comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [Thanks State Records NSW] Between 1887 (James Barnet rebuild) and 1896 (Walter Liberty Vernon additions), see www.sydneyarchitecture.com/ROC/QUA05.htm . See also comments here - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5215291939/] and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3794327782/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Note the streets paved with woodblocks. And no trams tracks. Should help us narrow the date further.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Trams were 1899; woodblocking first done in 1887 at Circular Quay - (SMH 16/8/1887, para 8) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28350536 . So no closer, except the woodblocks do look shiny and new (they mistakenly used the wrong unseasoned wood and the blocks rotted - letter from John Young in SMH 3/7/1894 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13958155 ) And the 'ghosts' imply a long exposure and earlier photographic techniques. I reckon this is a record of the newly completed Customs House and newly woodblocked Circular Quay in 1887. Or not?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] We can practically hear your brain ticking this one over! 1887-1896 is a great start and more than we had.

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Whirr - buzz - tick - tock - bleep . . . . ! The 1887 date on the building is easier to see on this Henry King photo or the persistent URL at full zoom - from.ph/31441 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362671311/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The square shaped lamp shade (see note) might provide a clue. Those very tall gas (?) lamps at Circular Quay are prominent in many old photos and a Streeton painting. Here they have a square shade, but later photos show round globes. square - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... round - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... The Henry King photo above has NO lamp on the pole!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a cropped version of this photo at investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... .

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks for the larger size to see the possible cast-iron posting box better. We can now see it certainly is an early posting box (note the vertical aperture), but whether or not it is the very first design as described, or a slightly later one, is hard to say - 'Local Improvements in Postal Matters', Empire, Tuesday 20 May 1856, p. 5:
... the first of the iron letter-receivers has been erected at the Circular Quay, within a short distance of the Custom House. The iron letter-receiver is a hollow cylinder of some two foot in diameter, and five feet three inches in height. Within a few inches of the top of the cylinder are three apertures, well protected from the weather by iron doors, which are affixed to the apertures by means of pivots, which enable the depositor to move the lids with the utmost facility. The letter inserted, the lid fulls over the aperture, and thus all accidents from rain, &c, are precluded.
- trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/60248171
